Single Responsibility Principle: One class should have only one reason to change.

- Signs of violating SRP:
  - Too many instance variables in a class
  - Too many public methods with implicit interface
  - Methods using different instances
  - Private methods that do extra work.


- Solution: Use collaborator class that handles minor tasks that are done in the main class.
---
Open Close Principle: We should change a class’s or add new features behavior without changing its source code.

- OCP from Robert C. Martin’s perspective: Reduce amount of change in open source
- OCP from Bertrand Meyer’s perspective: Changes should not disturb the working software and releasing a new version should not break the old ones.
- Signs of violating OCP:

  - Codes that determine the strategy (which class should be instantiated).
  - Conditions that manage object creation.
  - Hard reference to other classes from current class.
  - Creating objects of other classes inside current class.
  - Existence of protected methods inside current class that changing it leads to changing the class.


- Solution: Use only abstract instances in the current class.
---
Liskov Substitution Principle: Classes that implement an interface or abstract class, should be completely replaceable.

- Signs of violating LSP:
  - A class can not provide a complete implementation for its interface, so some methods have an empty implementation.
  - Return types should match the interface inside the derived classes.
  - There are conditions that will not be applied to all sub-classes.
  - Sub-class has some public methods in addition to the base class.


- Solution to violation #1: Interface isolation technique
- Solution to violation #2: Only happens in weakly typed languages.
- Solution to violation #3: Interface isolation technique
- Solution to violation #4: Interface isolation technique
---
Interface Segregation Principle: Interfaces should be fine-grained, meaning they should only have necessary methods aligning the client’s requirements.

- Signs of violating ISP:
  - The interface can be used in numerous different use cases.
  - Knowledge Sharing: Using concrete classes inside method, especially constructors, instead of interfaces as parameters.


- Solution: Interface isolation technique
---
[Dependency Inversion Principle](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Solid/DIP): Dependency should be defined on abstraction, not concretion. We should not be aware of implementation details, and this lack of awareness can help us in replacement stage. Client class does not determine the required type, it only determines the required rule and system will provide the specific type.

- Signs of violating DIP:
  - High level class depends on low level class.
  - Vendor Lock-In: A package is developed using a framework and can not be used with other technologies.


- Solution to violation #2: Adapter design pattern.
---
[Factory Method Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/FactoryMethod): A creational design pattern that provides and interface to create objects inside super-class, but allows the sub-class to determine the type.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

- Applicability of factory method:
  - When I don’t know beforehand the exact types and dependencies of objects my code should work with.
  - When I want to provide users of my library or framework with a way to extend its internal components.
  - When I want to save system resources by reusing existing objects instead of rebuilding them each time.

- Implementation: I create 2 folders, **creators** and **products**.

**products:** XProduct, YProduct, ZProduct

**creators:** XProductCreator, YProductCreator, ZProductCreator

We’ll have an abstract class called **ProductCreator** that is the base class for creator classes. There is an abstract method called **CreateProduct()** inside it, which returns a **Product**. These is an abstract method inside product classes that implements a major task of the product.

---

[Abstract Factory Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/AbstractFactory): A creational design pattern that helps us generate a family of related objects regardless of their implementations.

- Applicability of abstract factory: I create different objects from a category without the client knowing the exact type of them.
---
[Builder Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Builder): A creational design pattern that helps us create complex objects with too many fields or repetitive objects in unit tests.

- Applicability of builder:
  - Get rid of telescopic constructors.
  - Create objects with different shapes from one product.
  - Create objects with a tree hierarchy.

- Implementation: We have a **Product** class which has too many fields and not all of them might be needed. We create a class called **ProductBuilder** which has all fields of **Product** with a private constructor. It contains a static method called **aProduct()** which returns an object of type **ProductBuilder**. This class also has one method for each field of the class that initializes the field and returns a **ProductBuilder**. This way we can call each method and initialize the corresponding field. At the end we call method **build()** which returns a **Product** and creates the object.
```
Product product = ProductBuilder.aProduct()
.withField1("Field 2")
.withField2("Field 2")
.build();
```

---
[Adapter Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Adapter): A structural design patter that is used for collaboration between objects with incompatible interfaces.

- Applicability of adapter:
  - When interface of an existing class like a library or third-party class is incompatible with my system’s interface.
  - Sub-classes that follow the same super-class have some common functionalities that cannot be moved to the super-class.

- Implementation: We have 2 packages: **adapters** and **providers** and an interface called **Provider** which defines the business rules of our system. The providers implement **Provider** interface. The adapters are classes that also implement **Provider** and have an instance field of the incompatible third-party API and maintain the compatibility.
---
[Bridge Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Bridge): A structural design patter to bridge interface or abstract classes that a close relationship, but must be developed separately.

- Applicability of bridge:
  - When a monolithic class that has different implementations for a functionality is divided into multiple services. Just like a class that can use multiple database servers. Both the class and the database server can have multiple implementations.
  - When I want to develop a class in multiple dimensions.
  - When I want to use various implementations in runtime.

- Implementation: we have an abstract class called **Method**, an interface called **Handler** and 2 packages: **methods** and **handlers**. Handlers implement **Handler** and methods extend **Method**. Inside class **Method**, there is an instance of **Handler** which is protected and is used inside implementation of abstract methods.
---
[Composite Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Composite): A structural design patter that allows us have a tree set of objects, while each leaf of the tree is like the others in terms of execution.

- Applicability of composite:
  - When I want to implement a tree-shaped hierarchy.
  - When I want the client to see simple objects (leaves) and complex object (composites) the same.

- Implementation: We have an interface called **Component** with a method called **operation()**, some classes called **Leaf** that implement **Component** and a class called **Composite** which implements **Component** and has a collection of **Component**s. The implementation of **operation()** in **Composite** is a loop over all objects inside the collection and calling **operation()** for each one.
---
[Decorator Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Decorator): A structural design patter that provides us adding new features and behaviors to an object through the runtime without changing its source code.

- Applicability of decorator:
  - When I want to add new behaviors to an object without changing or breaking current code.
  - When I could not or would not use inheritance for adding new behaviors to the object. Like non-abstract classes that we better use composition.

- Implementation: We have an interface called **Provider**, an interface called **ProviderDecorator** that implements **Provider** and has some decorative methods and some classes that implement **Provider**. Inside the service class, we define 2 instabces: **provider** and **providerDecorator**. We can have access to both base methods through provider instance and extra methods through the decorator instance.
---
[Facade Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Facade): A structural design patter that implements a simple API which is involved with several classes and interfaces and reduces dependency.

- Implementation: Several tasks of a class are divided into multiple classes and are called serially.
---
[Proxy Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Proxy): A structural design patter that is used as an interface and validates access to an object that can impose cost on the system.

- Applicability of proxy:
  - Lazy Initialization: like a service that can use a massive amount resource or have a cost and I want it to be used only in certain situations, and not in all requests.
  - For caching heavy resources.
  - Controlling over requests to a service that has a limit.
---
[Flyweight Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/FlyWeight): A structural design patter that makes it possible to do a heavy load of processes real-time and hold the data inside RAM. It stores the shared data inside a buffer to prevent duplication.

- Applicability of flyweight: we use this design pattern only when new need to hold a large amount of data inside RAM.
- Implementation: If class **X** has 7 fields, that 2 of them is unique for each instance, but the combination of the other fields can be duplicated, we put these 5 fields inside another class called **XConstraint** and define a field of type **XConstraint** inside class **X**. We define a map with string keys and **XConstraint** values inside the client class which stores the shared objects along side their hash code. Every time an object of type **X** is created in method **create()** of class **XFactory**, we check if its **XConstraint** exists in the map; if so, it is read from the map and will not be instantiated.
---
[Chain Of Responsibility Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/ChainOfResponsibility): A behavioral design pattern that is used when a chain of commands is going to be executed, and each link decides if the next one should be executed.

- Applicability of chain of responsibility:
  - When the program expects different kinds of requests, but their type is not known and the order is not determined.
  - When it is required that the handlers be executed in a specific order.
  - When it is required that the handler and their order be changed during the runtime.

- Implementation: There is an abstract class called **Validator** that has a field of its own type called **nextValidator**, a constructor that initializes **nextValidator** and a boolean method called **validate()** that returns true if **nextValidator** is null; or calls **validate()** on **nextValidator** and returns the result. There is a package called **validators** containing classes that extend the **Validator** abstract class and a service class that instantiates validator classes in a specific order. Constructor of the first chain link gets null as argument, and each link is used as the argument for the next validator’s constructor.
---
[Command Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Command): A behavioral design pattern that converts a command to an object that can be queued, can be undone or can be scheduled.

- Applicability of command:
  - We I want to pass operations to method as parameters.
  - When I want to enqueue or schedule an operation.
  - When I want to pass an operation to another service, instead of running it on the current service.
  - When I want an operation to be undoable.

- Implementation: We have 3 packages: **commands**, **handlers** and **invoker**. Inside **commands**, there is in interface called **Command** that has a method called **execute()**. There is one class for each operation that implements **Command**.

Inside package **handlers**, there is one class for each command class which implements the logic for the corresponding command class. Each command class has an instance of its handler type which is used inside method **execute()**.

Inside package **invoker**, is a client that uses the required command and handler classes and executes the operation.

---

[Observer Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Observer): A behavioral design pattern that creates classes that are notified when an object changes. This design pattern is usually used on models and domain objects.

- Applicability of observer:
  - When changing state of an object should change other objects and we don’t know which objects should be affected.
  - When it is required to track an object for a limited time.

- Implementation: There is a package called **contracts** containing:
- An interface called **Observer** with a method called **update(Subject subject)**
- An interface called **Subject** with 3 methods:
- **attach(String name, Observer observer)**
- **detach(String name, Observer observer)**
- **notifySubscribers()**
- A class called **ObserverStorage** which contains:
- A map of strings and **Observer**s.
- A method called **attach(String name, Observer observer)** that adds a new element to the map.
- A method called **detach(String name, Observer observer)** that removes an element from the map.

We have a class called **Product** that implements **Subject** and has field of type **ObserverStorage**, a class called **ProductObserver** that implement **Observer**.

---
[State Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/State): A behavioral design pattern that changes behavior of an object when its state changes. Some operations will be locked or unlocked for the object based on its state.

- Applicability of state:
  -  When an objects behavior should change based on its state, and these changes happen frequently or has too many states.
  - If different values of class fields lead to different behaviors for the class and it requires a lot of if-else statements to be handled.
  - When we have a finite state machine and different states have duplicated code and we need to reduce it.

- Implementation: We have a package called **states** contaning an interface called **ProductStatus** and classes that implement **ProductStatus** and define the behavior of the class in different states. There is also one method for each status inside **ProductStatus** which is abstract and should be implemented inside sub-classes.
---
[Strategy Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Strategy): A behavioral design pattern that is used when a job is implemented in different algorithms, and lets us switch between them.

- Applicability of strategy:
  - Switch between different algorithms in runtime.
  - When similar classes have difference only in minor behaviors.
  - To isolate business logic from implementation details of a class that is not related to the context of the class.

- Implementation: There are 2 packages: **methods** and **clients**. Methods are the interface and classes that implement different strategies to execute a task. Inside **Client** class, we define a field of type **Method** which is injected through the constructor and a method called **setMethod(Method method)** to change the strategy in runtime.
---
[Template Method Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/TemplateMethod): A behavioral design pattern that provides us to call methods in a specific order, but each method could have several implementations.

- Applicability of template method:
  - When I want to let my client to change only part of the process, not the general structure.
  - When I have multiple classes doing almost the same job and differ only in minor details.

- Implementation: we have an abstract class called **Base**, which has a public method called **process()** and some abstract protected methods. **process()** does the main operation and calls abstract methods in a specific order. Abstract methods are protected and implemented in other sub-classes.
---
[Visitor Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Visitor): A behavioral design pattern that isolates the algorithm from the object(element) that the work is supposed to be applied to. It makes adding new features and behaviors(visitor) to the object easier. Element and visitor are both interfaces and provide us with this possibility to add new features without violating Open-Closed principle.

- Applicability of visitor:
  - When I want to run an algorithm to all elements of a complex object or object tree.
  - To isolate business logic from implementation of general logics.
  - When an algorithm should be applied only on some of elements of a hierarchy.

- Implementation: we have:
    - An interface called **Component** with a method called **accept(Visitor visitor)** that can accept or refuse an implementation for an object.
    - An interface called **Visitor** that has one method for each component.
    - Algorithm classes that implement **Visitor**.
    - A package called **components** containing classes that implement **Component**.
---
[Mediator Design Pattern](https://github.com/mmahdi-farrokhy/DesignPatterns/tree/main/DesignPatterns/src/main/java/Mediator): A behavioral design pattern that is used as an interface between objects when we cannot create a direct dependency.

- Applicability of mediator:
  - When a class is tightly coupled with other classes and makes it difficult to change the class.
  - When a class has too close relation with other classes that can not be used in other programs.
